accessibility-statement.heading: Accessibility statement for the HMCTS video hearing service
accessibility-statement.paragraph1: This accessibility statement applies to the Video Hearings service available at: video.hearings.reform.hmcts.net. This service allows all participants to take part in a court or tribunal hearing by video - from their home, office, or somewhere else using a laptop or desktop computer.
accessibility-statement.paragraph2: This website is run by His Majesty’s Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS). We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website. On this website, you should be able to:

list.1: navigate most of the website using just a keyboard; and
list.2: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver).

accessibility-statement.paragraph3: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

how-accessible.paragraph1: We know some parts of this website are not fully accessible:
how-accessible.heading: How accessible is this service?

list.1: The self-test feature, for testing computer equipment in advance of a video hearing, is not accessible for visually impaired people.
list.2: Screen reader users may experience issues using the following sections of the application:
list.3: People needing to use their keyboard for navigation may experience the following issues:
list.4: Users with low vision may have issues reading the text on the platform, due to there being not enough contrast between text and its background
list.5: Users with visual impairments may have issues using the Instant Messaging feature in the Hearing Room. They will be able to listen to most of the website using a screen reader.

sub-list1.1: Viewing the Participant List in the Waiting Room.
sub-list1.2: Navigating the in-hearing controls in the Hearing Room.
sub-list1.3: Selecting a hearing from the Hearing List.
sub-list1.4: Selecting the Camera, Microphone, and the Instant Messaging feature in the Waiting Room.

sub-list2.1: Selecting the Camera and Microphone from the Waiting Room.
sub-list2.3: Navigating the in-hearing controls in the Hearing Room

how-accessible.paragraph2: We want as many people as possible to be able to use our service, we are therefore working to further develop the Video Hearings platform, so that it is accessible for all our users. Our aim is to ensure that improvements are in place by July 2023.

feedback.heading: Feedback and contact information
feedback.paragraph1: Contact the court or tribunal that arranged your hearing if: you feel you cannot attend your hearing by video; if you have additional needs; if you need information about our service in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read, audio recording or braille.
feedback.paragraph2: If you have a notice of hearing, you can find the court and tribunal contact details there.
feedback.paragraph3: If you know the name of the court or tribunal, you can search for their contact details at.
feedback.paragraph4: If you have technical questions about your Video Hearing, or if you are experiencing technical difficulties with your equipment, such as your camera or microphone not working, then please contact the video hearings team using the details below:
feedback.paragraph7: If you email us, include the location of your court or tribunal centre and case number in the subject line.
feedback.paragraph8: We aim to respond to emails the same working day.

list.1: call {{phoneNumber}} between 9am and 5pm, Monday to Friday

list-scotland.1: call {{phoneNumber}} between 9am and 5pm, between 8.30am and 5pm, Monday to Friday

reporting-accessibility.heading: Reporting accessibility problems with this service
reporting-accessibility.paragraph1: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of our service. If you find any problems that aren’t listed on this page or think we’re not meeting the requirements of the accessibility regulations contact:

enforcement-procedure.heading: Enforcement procedure
enforcement-procedure.paragraph1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
enforcement-procedure.paragraph2: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS)

contacting-us.heading: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
contacting-us.paragraph1: We provide a text relay service if you’re deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
contacting-us.paragraph2: Our offices have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit, we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.
contacting-us.link:: Find a court or tribunal - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk)

technical-information.heading: Technical information about the Video Hearings service’s accessibility
technical-information.paragraph1: HM Courts and Tribunals Service is committed to making its services accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

compliance-status.heading: Compliance status
compliance-status.paragraph1.1: Our service is partially compliant with the
compliance-status.paragraph1.2: AA standard due to the non-compliances listed below.

non-accessible-content.heading: Non accessible content
non-accessible-content.paragraph1: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
non-accessible-content.paragraph2: The self-test feature means that users need to test their computer equipment in advance of their video hearing. A video plays and the user is prompted to count to 5 out loud to check their microphone is working. The microphone volume indicator relies on sight and does not convey information to visually impaired users. This fails WCAG success criteria 1.1.1 (non-text content) and 1.3.3 (sensory characteristics).
non-accessible-content.paragraph3: The self-test feature is scheduled for redesign by July 2024.
non-accessible-content.paragraph4: Screen reader users may experience issues using some sections of the application. Viewing the Participant List in Waiting Room fails WCAG success criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships). Navigating to the in-hearing controls in the Hearing Room fails WCAG success criteria 2.4.3 (Focus Order). Selecting a hearing from the Hearing List fails WCAG success criterion 2.4.6 (Headings and Labels), as does Selecting Camera and Microphone from the Waiting Room. The Instant Messaging feature in the Waiting Room fails WCAG success criterion 4.1.3. (Status Messages) as the character count is not read out to users.
non-accessible-content.paragraph5: These features are due to be incorporated onto the Video Hearings Platform by March 2023.
non-accessible-content.paragraph6: Users reliant on using the keyboard for navigation may experience issues some sections of the application. Selecting Camera and Microphone from the Waiting Room fails WCAG success criterion 2.4.3 (Focus Order), as does Leaving a Consultation. Navigating to the in-hearing controls in the Hearing Room fails WCAG success criterion 1.4.12 (Content on Hover or Focus).
non-accessible-content.paragraph7: These features are due to be incorporated onto the Video Hearings Platform by March 2023.
non-accessible-content.paragraph8: Users with low vision may have issues using the Instant Messaging feature in the Hearing Room. This fails WCAG success criterion 1.4.2 (Contrast (Minimum)). Users will be able to listen to most of the website using a screen reader.

improving-accessibility.heading: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
improving-accessibility.paragraph1: The Video Hearings service is continually tested by HMCTS using automated tests and with accessibility software. Any new features which are introduced are also tested. This helps us to resolve issues before we launch new pages or features.
improving-accessibility.paragraph2: The platform can be used in advance of a video hearing to enable a user to change their password and test their computer equipment. This aspect of the website was assessed by the Digital Accessibility Centre in September 2019.
improving-accessibility.paragraph3: The platform is used to enable a user to attend their video hearing. This aspect of the website was assessed by the Digital Accessibility Centre in April 2021.
improving-accessibility.paragraph4: Departments and agencies are urgently fixing issues which fail to meet the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard. We will update this page when issues are fixed.
improving-accessibility.paragraph5.1: By Spring 2020 we’ll review the way we help users test their equipment to address the accessibility issues identified in the DAC report.
improving-accessibility.paragraph5.2: shows how and when we plan to improve accessibility on the video hearings platform..

how-we-tested-this-website.heading: How we tested this website
how-we-tested-this-website.paragraph1: The website was tested by the Digital Accessibility Centre, Neath, during September 2019.
how-we-tested-this-website.paragraph2: This is an excerpt from their report explaining their methodology:
how-we-tested-this-website.paragraph3: The website was tested by a team of experienced auditors, many of who are disabled individuals and users of adaptive technology. The combination of subjective pan-disability user feedback and comprehensive technical auditing allows us to measure how the website performs technically and practically, thereby offering an essential added dimension to our test results that other methods of testing cannot provide.
how-we-tested-this-website.paragraph4: Manual accessibility checking was conducted by a team of disabled individuals, using a range of adaptive technologies (hardware and software designed to facilitate the use of computers by people with disabilities).
how-we-tested-this-website.paragraph5: Technical auditing involves the experienced application of a number of technical auditing and standards compliance assessment tools. This combined with an extensive knowledge of WCAG, its application and wider global practice provides the DAC website with further credibility and quality.

privacy-policy.heading: Our privacy policy for the video hearings service
privacy-policy.paragraph1: The video hearings service is managed by HM Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS).
privacy-policy.paragraph2: When you use this service we (HMCTS) will ask you to provide some personal data. This policy explains why we collect your personal data, what we do with it and your rights.

why-we-collect.heading: Why we collect your personal data
why-we-collect.paragraph: We collect your personal data so you can take part in a video hearing and to meet legal requirements. We also collect data to improve the service.

what-we-do.heading: What we do with your personal data
what-we-do.paragraph1: Your personal data is processed by our staff in the UK, and the data is stored within the EEA.
what-we-do.paragraph2: HMCTS is an executive agency of the Ministry of Justice. The Ministry of Justice is known as the 'data controller' of the personal data you provide. The Ministry's personal information charter explains more about how we process data.

what-we-collect.heading: The data we collect
what-we-collect.paragraph: The personal data we collect includes:

list.1: your name, address and contact details, including your email address and telephone number
list.2: details of your company and your role, if applicable
list.3: details of anyone who acts on your behalf or anyone that you act for in a video hearing
list.4: information we gather to assess your suitability for a video hearing
list.6: information that tells us if you open an email from us, or click on a link in an email
list.7: the login details you use to access the video hearings service
list.8: information about the way you access this service including your IP address, internet speed, computer operating system and the browser you use to access the internet. We do this by

how-long.heading: How long we keep your data
how-long.paragraph: The video hearings service will keep this information for 3 months after the date your hearing is booked to take place. We'll then delete it. Information about your application or your case is held by a different department in HMCTS and different arrangements may apply.

shoring-and-sharing.heading: Storing and sharing your data internationally
shoring-and-sharing.paragraph: Sometimes your personal data will be stored outside the UK. When we do this, we comply with data protection law.

your-rights.heading: Your rights

list-ask.1: to see the personal data that we hold on you
list-ask.2: to have the personal data corrected
list-ask.3: to have the personal data removed or deleted (this will depend on the circumstances, for example, if you decide not to continue with your case)
list-ask.4: that access to the personal data is restricted (for example, you can ask to have your data stored for longer and not automatically deleted)

your-rights.paragraph2: If you want to see the personal data that we hold on you, you can:

list-see.1-2: Your request goes to the MoJ as data controller.
list-see.2: write to us: Disclosure Team, Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ

your-rights.paragraph3: You can ask for more information about:

list-more.1: agreements we have on sharing information with other organisations
list-more.2: when we are allowed to pass on personal information without telling you
list-more.3: our instructions to staff on how to collect, use or delete your personal information
list-more.4: how we check that the information we hold is accurate and up to date

your-rights.paragraph4: You can contact the MoJ data protection officer by:

list-contact.1: writing to us: Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ

how-to-complain.heading: How to complain
how-to-complain.paragraph1-2: if you want to complain about how we've handled your personal data.
how-to-complain.paragraph2-1: Write to: Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ
how-to-complain.paragraph3-1: You can also complain to the
how-to-complain.paragraph3-2: if you're not satisfied with our response or believe we're not processing your personal data lawfully.

hearings-recorded.heading: Where hearings are recorded
hearings-recorded.paragraph1: The process for recording video hearings is the same as for hearings held in a court or tribunal building:

list.1: hearings at the Crown Court and at civil and family courts are always recorded
list.2-1: tribunal hearings are not always recorded.
list.2-2: to find out if the hearing was recorded.
list.3: hearings at magistrates' courts are never recorded.

hearings-recorded.paragraph2-1: Where hearings are recorded you may
hearings-recorded.paragraph3: Participants must not record or take any images of the hearing.

hearing-started.title: Alert!
hearing-started.message: The hearing is now in session.

idp-selection.title: Select your account type to sign in
idp-selection.description: You must sign in with the right kind of user account. Check the user name you were sent and select from the following options:
idp-selection.warning: You will get an error message if you sign in with the wrong account type. Please check carefully before selecting.

quick-participant-landing-page.page-title: Enter your details to join your hearing
quick-participant-landing-page.paragraph1: Please tell us your name and your role in the hearing.
quick-participant-landing-page.problem-with-special-char: You entered some characters that are not allowed.
quick-participant-landing-page.problem-with-special-char-recommendation: You may use accents, apostrophes and hyphens but no other symbols.
quick-participant-landing-page.name-error-special-char: You've entered characters that are not allowed
quick-participant-landing-page.role-label: What is your role in the hearing?
quick-participant-landing-page.role-error: Please choose your role in the hearing

QuickLinkParticipant.title: Participant
QuickLinkParticipant.description: You have been called to take part in the hearing.

QuickLinkObserver.title: Observer
QuickLinkObserver.description: You are observing the hearing, but not taking part.

invalid-page.heading: The link you've used can't be recognised
invalid-page.body: Please check the link you were sent. If it still doesn't work, call 0300 303 0655 for immediate contact with a video hearings officer.

video-filter.title: Choose a custom background
video-filter.hmcts-alt: Apply the background with the HMCTS crest
video-filter.scts-alt: Apply the background with the SCTS crest

feedback-banner.title: We'd like your opinion
feedback-banner.body: Before you go, how was your experience of the Video Hearings Service?
